content: Lifestyle Career Asked by AnonymousAsked on 06 Dec 2018Whenever my colleagues are in a group conversation, they talk about world affairs and finance, and politics. What should I do if I always have nothing to contribute to the discussion?I've actually tried reading up on them but felt like there's so much information out there and I can't understand or even remember all of them5 answersAnswerBump0

Leong Wen Fong, Economics and Management at University of LondonLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 07 Dec 2018Agree with a lot of people that you should first start by listening. Watch or listen to the news! (Or read about it) and be diligent in finding out about the things you don't understand.I learnt that every time you have spare time, it's a choice between education and amusement. When we spend so much time on amusement (eg. dramas and games), it doesn't add value to us. Not that you shouldn't do it, but you should limit the time on that, and spend some time on education instead!0 comments1

Yong Kah HweeLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 06 Dec 2018Try to ask questions! Even if you think the question sounds dumb, just ask! if you don't ask, you'll never know what it is they are talking about :)0 comments1

Luke Ho, Money Maverick at Money MaverickLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 06 Dec 2018Typically you can start by researching information most aligned with your values. I think the reason they talk about these affairs is because they obviously feel some sort of personal alignment to them. Kick back and listen and figure out their motivations, before you  can figure out yours and do reading into what you're interested in. There are many hard questions and ugly truths that can be revealed by economics and politics, and they're necessary for you to keep pushing forward in a largely unfair world, so start from things you feel strongly about so that you learn more aboout yourself as well. 0 comments0
